statement:
*Fitting’s Theorem* states that if $G$ is a group and $M$ and $N$ are
normal nilpotent of $G$, then $MN$ is also a normal nilpotent subgroup
(of nilpotency class less than or equal to the sum of the nilpotency
classes of $M$ and $N$).

Thus, any finite group has a unique largest normal nilpotent subgroup,
called its *Fitting subgroup*. More generally, the Fitting subgroup of a
group $G$ is defined to be the subgroup of $G$ generated by the normal
nilpotent subgroups of $G$; Fitting’s Theorem shows that the Fitting
subgroup is always locally nilpotent. A group that is equal to its own
Fitting subgroup is sometimes called a *Fitting group*.
